message_1: If the probability of studying mathematics leading to a high-paying job is 0.8, and the probability of not studying mathematics and still getting a high-paying job is 0.2, what is the causal effect of studying mathematics on the probability of getting a high-paying job?
message_2:
The causal effect of studying mathematics on the probability of getting a high-paying job can be calculated by finding the difference between the probability of getting a high-paying job when studying mathematics and the probability of getting a high-paying job when not studying mathematics.

Causal effect = P(high-paying job | studying mathematics) - P(high-paying job | not studying mathematics)

Causal effect = 0.8 - 0.2

Causal effect = 0.6

So, the causal effect of studying mathematics on the probability of getting a high-paying job is 0.6 or 60%.
